Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the kidneys, joints, and heart, with manifestations like nephritis, arthropathy, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder primarily affecting joints but can also cause extra-articular manifestations such as pericarditis and, rarely, nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A disorder featuring manifestations of lupus, scleroderma, polymyositis, and rheumatoid arthritis including arthritis, pericarditis, and sometimes nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease with widespread fibrosis, affecting the skin, heart (pericarditis), kidneys (nephritis), and joints (arthropathy).

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.description: A form of arthritis affecting the spine and large joints, and can include cardiac manifestations like pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, affecting skin and joints and may occasionally involve the kidneys and heart.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Pericarditis resulting from infectious causes like bacteria, viruses, or fungi, which can also lead to systemic inflammation affecting other organs.

diagnoses.name: Uremic Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: A form of pericarditis occurring in the setting of uremia, commonly due to severe chronic kidney disease or acute kidney failure.

diagnoses.name: Drug-Induced Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder induced by certain medications, mirroring symptoms of systemic lupus erythematosus including arthralgia, nephritis, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A multi-system inflammatory disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas in multiple organs, including potential cardiac (pericarditis) and renal (nephritis) involvement.

diagnoses: Epilepsy (due to CNS lupus or vasculitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by symptoms like fever, joint pain (arthropathy), and skin manifestations such as follicular hyperkeratosis. Patients may also develop pericardial effusion as part of cardiovascular involvement.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause systemic symptoms such as fever and skin manifestations. In some cases, it can lead to pericardial effusion due to inflammation spreading to the heart's surrounding tissues.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. Skin changes, including follicular hyperkeratosis, fever, arthralgia, and pericardial effusion, can occur when the disease involves the heart (cardiac sarcoidosis).

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A form of arthritis that affects some individuals diagnosed with psoriasis. It can cause swollen, painful joints (arthropathy) and also present with fever. Follicular hyperkeratosis can often be seen in areas of skin involvement.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: A rare inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It can cause joint pain (arthropathy), fever, and in rare cases, pericardial effusion due to its systemic nature.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that shows signs similar to several connective tissue diseases, like lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. Symptoms can include joint pain (arthropathy), fever, skin rash, and occasionally, pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Adult-onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare inflammatory disorder that can lead to fever, joint pain (arthropathy), and a salmon-colored rash. In severe cases, it can lead to complications like pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia burgdorferi bacteria, transmitted to humans through the bite of infected black-legged ticks. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fever, arthralgia, and in rare cases, pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that cause the skin and connective tissues to harden and tighten. Symptoms can include skin changes like follicular hyperkeratosis, joint pain (arthropathy), fever, and in severe cases, pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: The Human Immunodeficiency Virus weakens the immune system by destroying important cells that fight disease and infections. Its associated condition, Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS), can lead to a wide range of symptoms including fever, joint pain (arthropathy), skin issues, and in some cases, pericardial effusion due to opportunistic infections or tumors.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis with Associated Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia
Viral-induced Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia (especially with EBV or HIV)
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by periods of illness, called flares, and periods of wellness, or remission.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It occurs when the immune system mistakenly attacks the body's tissues.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It often accompanies other immune system disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. Symptoms may include mouth sores, genital sores, inflammation inside the eye, and skin problems.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. This causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. It amplifies painful sensations by affecting the way your brain processes pain signals.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: The growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body, most commonly the lungs, lymph nodes, eyes, and skin.

diagnoses.name: Epstein-Barr Virus Infection
diagnoses.description: A common virus that causes mononucleosis. It's a member of the herpes virus family and is spread through bodily fluids, primarily saliva.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic disorder that results in recurring attacks of angioedema. The swelling can occur in the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness.

diagnoses: Graves' Disease (a common cause of hyperthyroidism)
Celiac Disease (a common cause of malabsorption)
Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (formerly Churg-Strauss Syndrome)
Squamous Cell Carcinoma (especially in the context of leukoplakia)

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Hyperglycemia is a hallmark symptom, potentially leading to complications that can exacerbate conditions such as ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.reasoning: Patients with COPD are prone to episodes of bronchitis and may exhibit symptoms like dysphagia due to overall weakened health status.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Pallor is a common symptom. Anemia can also contribute to the exacerbation of other conditions, potentially influencing ulcers and overall energy levels.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly relates to the presence of ulcers and might also be connected with dysphagia in severe cases or when esophageal involvement is present.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause a wide range of symptoms including ulcers, and potentially related to the systemic features like pallor.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.reasoning: Dysphagia often occurs with GERD, and chronic acid reflux can lead to complications affecting overall health, potentially influencing symptoms like ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Diseases (e.g., Tuberculosis)
diagnoses.reasoning: Could explain the presence of bronchitis and pallor, especially in chronic or severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Pernicious Anemia
diagnoses.reasoning: This form of anemia can lead to pallor and could be involved in the exacerbation of other symptoms, such as dysphagia due to the associated neurological complications.

diagnoses.name: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
diagnoses.reasoning: Dysphagia is a key symptom. As cancer progresses, it may lead to systemic impacts, including pallor, and contribute to the development of ulcers indirectly through overall health degradation.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: Can present with a broad array of symptoms including ulcers and systemic signs like pallor due to compromised immune system function.

diagnoses: Blepharospasm as part of Dystonia Syndromes
Vision-related Strain or Computer Vision Syndrome

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Turner syndrome, a condition that affects only females, results when one of the X chromosomes (sex chromosomes) is missing or partially missing. It can lead to delayed puberty and is associated with aortic root dilatation, which can contribute to atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs and body systems. Lupus can lead to lymphadenopathy and chest pain due to pericarditis. In severe cases, it can also contribute to atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: This type of cancer of the lymphatic system can cause lymphadenopathy and has been associated with an increased risk for atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Delayed puberty and a higher prevalence of endometriosis have been reported in individuals with this syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Klinefelter Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic condition affecting males that results from an extra X chromosome. It commonly leads to delayed puberty and can be associated with increased risk of cardiovascular problems, such as atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Familial Hypercholesterolemia
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder characterized by high cholesterol levels, specifically very high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL, or 'bad' cholesterol), leading to atherosclerosis at a young age.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is cancer of the lymphatic system. It can lead to symptoms such as enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) and, indirectly, various cardiovascular risks.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It can cause lymphadenopathy and has been linked to an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, such as atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An inherited disorder that affects connective tissue — the fibers that support and anchor your organs and other structures in your body. It can lead to a variety of cardiovascular issues, including atherosclerosis, and may affect pubertal development.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects a woman’s hormone levels, leading to various symptoms including potential endometriosis exacerbation. It can also increase the risk of developing metabolic syndrome, which is closely linked to atherosclerosis.

diagnoses: Dermatologic conditions (e.g., eczema, psoriasis, contact dermatitis)

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting, occurring in response to a trigger, such as stress or pain, leading to sudden drop in heart rate and blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Orthostatic hypotension
diagnoses.description: A form of low blood pressure that happens when standing up from sitting or lying down, which can lead to dizziness and fainting.

diagnoses.name: Seizure disorders
diagnoses.description: Seizures can lead to a loss of consciousness, involuntary movements, and loss of bladder control.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can cause low blood pressure, fainting, and incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Addison's disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the adrenal glands that can cause abdominal pain, severe weakness, low blood pressure, fainting, and craving for salt.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the digestive track that causes abdominal cramps, sometimes leading to hypotension through dehydration.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of the adrenal gland tissue that can cause episodes of high blood pressure, palpitations, abdominal pain, headaches, and sweating. In some cases, hypotension can follow these episodes.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A condition affecting the autonomic nervous system, causing abnormalities in blood pressure regulation and bowel and bladder control.

diagnoses.name: Neurocardiogenic syncope
diagnoses.description: A condition that leads to fainting due to a temporary drop in the amount of blood flowing to the brain, often triggered by pain or emotional distress.

diagnoses.name: Acute poisoning
diagnoses.description: Exposure to toxic substances can cause a range of symptoms including abdominal cramps, low blood pressure, and loss of consciousness.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Allergic reaction to food or medication
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Asthmatic attack with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) complications
Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with associated respiratory allergic reaction
Shellfish allergy or other specific food allergies

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe throbbing and pulsating pain on one side of the head. The aura phase includes symptoms such as visual disturbances, aphasia, or sensory disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief interruption of blood flow to part of the brain, spinal cord, or retina, causing stroke-like symptoms such as paralysis, aphasia, and dizziness/vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include headache, trouble speaking and understanding (aphasia), and imbalance or vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
diagnoses.description: A disorder arising in the inner ear. Its symptoms are repeated episodes of positional vertigo, a spinning sensation caused by changes in the position of the head, sometimes accompanied by nausea and rarely migraine-like symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, tinnitus, a feeling of fullness or pressure in the ear, and fluctuating hearing loss. It might cause headache and sound sensitivity in some cases.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can be cancerous or noncancerous. Depending on its location, it may cause headache, seizures, aphasia, and vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular migraine
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that primarily presents with vertigo along with migraine symptoms such as headaches, photophobia, and phonophobia but might not always include a headache phase.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis
diagnoses.description: A blood clot of the dural venous sinuses, which drain blood from the brain. Symptoms may include headache, blurred vision, fainting or loss of consciousness, reduced ability to move parts of the body, aphasia, and vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune, inflammatory neurological disease of the central nervous system. MS can present with vertigo, sensory disturbances, aphasia if there are lesions in the speech areas, and in severe cases, headaches.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. While not common, it can manifest with aphasia, and less commonly headache or photophobia following seizures.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. It interrupts the flow of information within the brain and between the brain and body. Symptoms include fatigue, numbness, tingling, blurred vision, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the fluid and membranes around the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms include headache, fever, and a stiff neck. Nausea, vomiting, increased sensitivity to light, and altered mental status can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: A form of stroke caused by bleeding into the space surrounding the brain. It can cause sudden onset headache, nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and decreased level of consciousness.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal cells grow in the brain. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, nausea, vomiting, weakness, and sensory changes like numbness or tingling.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include headache, fever, fatigue, and a characteristic skin rash. If untreated, infection can spread to the joints, heart, and nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Chemical Poisoning
diagnoses.description: Exposure to chemical substances can result in symptoms like headache, nausea, dizziness, weakness, and numbness or tingling. Severity depends on the chemical involved, the amount of exposure, and the age and underlying health of the exposed individual.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.description: A condition that produces severe headaches on one side of the head. It can be accompanied by tearing, nasal congestion, eye redness, and more. Cluster headache sufferers may also experience nausea and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms include fatigue, increased sensitivity to cold, constipation, dry skin, weight gain, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. A stroke is a medical emergency, and prompt treatment is crucial. Early action can reduce brain damage and other complications.
symptoms: hearing loss (rare, usually indicative of a more complex stroke)

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant).

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) is a noncancerous and usually slow-growing tumor that develops on the main nerve leading from your inner ear to your brain. Because branches of this nerve directly influence your balance and hearing, pressure from an acoustic neuroma can cause hearing loss, ringing in your ear and unsteadiness.
symptoms: numbness (if the tumor affects nearby nerves)
weakness (rare, unless tumor is large or affects certain brain areas)

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. A TIA is a warning you're at risk of a true stroke in the near future.

diagnoses.name: Ménière's Disease
diagnoses.description: Ménière's disease is a disorder of the inner ear that causes severe dizziness (vertigo), ringing in the ears (tinnitus), hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness or congestion in the ear. Ménière's disease usually affects only one ear.
symptoms: weakness and numbness (not direct symptoms, but can result from falls or accidents due to vertigo)

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis
diagnoses.description: Neurofibromatosis is a genetic disorder that causes tumors to form on nerve tissue. These tumors can develop anywhere in your nervous system, including your brain, spinal cord, and nerves. Neurofibromatosis is usually diagnosed in childhood or early adulthood.
symptoms: hearing loss (if tumor affects auditory nerves)

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme disease is a bacterial infection you get from the bite of an infected tick. The first sign is usually a bull's-eye rash. Early symptoms can also include fever, headache, and fatigue. If not treated, the infection can spread to the joints, heart, and nervous system.
symptoms: facial palsy can appear as aphasia

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.
symptoms: aphasia (rare, usually due to weakness or coordination issues rather than actual language processing)

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection. Brain abscesses can develop from an ear infection, sinus infection, trauma, or after surgery.
symptoms: hearing loss (if abscess affects related areas)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by severe head pain, visual disturbances (aura), sensitivity to light (photophobia), and sometimes nausea and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inner ear disorder that can affect hearing and balance, leading to vertigo, hearing loss, ringing in the ear (tinnitus), and sometimes a feeling of fullness or pressure in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuronitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the vestibular nerve, which can cause sudden, severe vertigo and difficulty balancing.

diagnoses.name: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
diagnoses.description: A disorder arising from a problem in the inner ear, characterized by short episodes of vertigo in relation to changes in the position of the head.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can include headache, seizures, vomiting, difficulty speaking or comprehending, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include headache, trouble walking, vertigo, and confusion.

diagnoses.name: Migrainous Vertigo (Vestibular Migraine)
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that might include episodes of severe dizziness or a feeling of spinning (vertigo).

diagnoses.name: Labrynthitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the inner ear or the nerves that connect the inner ear to the brain, leading to vertigo, hearing loss, and difficulty balancing.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause various neuropsychological symptoms including visual disturbances and difficulty coordinating movement.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by high pressure in the spaces around the brain and spinal cord, leading to symptoms like headache, nausea, vomiting, pulsatile tinnitus, double vision, and other visual symptoms.

diagnoses: Viral infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, given no direct relation, this reflects a comorbid condition)
Lupus Erythematosus, Systemic with neuropsychiatric manifestations
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Epilepsy (for seizures, but further specification needed for accurate diagnosis)
